First, when we examine the life cycle of both energy sources—coal and nuclear—nuclear consistently comes out with a far better safety record. According to the most widely cited study by the renowned energy researcher Mark Z. Jacobson and the University of California, as well as the 2014 study published in *Energy Policy* by Pushker Kharecha and James Hansen, coal is responsible for thousands to tens of thousands of premature deaths per terawatt-hour (TWh) of electricity generated. These deaths come from air pollution—specifically from particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and mercury emissions—linked to respiratory diseases, heart conditions, and cancer.

In stark contrast, nuclear energy results in significantly fewer deaths per TWh. The same studies show that nuclear power causes less than 1% of the deaths per unit of energy compared to coal. Even when accounting for major accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima, the death toll per unit of energy is still far lower than coal's annual death toll.

For instance, the World Health Organization estimates that around 800,000 people die each year from air pollution related to coal use—globally. That’s not just an accident or a rare event; it’s the routine, ongoing cost of burning coal. Meanwhile, nuclear accidents are rare, and even the worst ones have had a relatively small death toll in the grand scheme of global energy production.

Nuclear energy doesn't just avoid emitting the harmful pollutants that coal does—it also avoids the mining-related fatalities that are all too common in the coal industry. Coal mining is one of the most dangerous occupations in the world, with thousands of miner deaths occurring globally each year. Again, nuclear doesn't have that risk.

So, in terms of deaths per unit of electricity generated, the math is clear: coal is vastly more deadly than nuclear. If we truly care about public health and saving lives, we must prioritize the energy sources with the highest safety records, and nuclear power undeniably fits that description.
